original: (a) Appointments.  Simultaneously with the execution and delivery of this Agreement, the Board and its committees shall take such actions (with such actions deemed to have to occurred substantially simultaneously) as are necessary (i) to increase the size of the Board from six (6) to ten (10) Directors, and (ii) to appoint each of Kenneth S. Courtis and Michael Gorzynski (the “ MG Capital Designees ”) and (iii) to appoint each of Avram A. Glazer and Shelly Lombard (together with the MG Capital Designees, the “ New Directors ”) to the Board.
ollama_generated: (b) Appointments and Board Adjustment. Upon the execution and delivery of this Agreement, the Board is given a reasonable timeframe to adjust its composition as follows: (i) increasing the number of Directors from six (6) to ten (10), (ii) appointing each of Kenneth S. Courtis and Michael Gorzynski (the “ MG Capital Designees ”), and (iii) concurrently, considering the appointment of Avram A. Glazer and Shelly Lombard (together with the MG Capital Designees, the “ Proposed Directors ”). If the Board fails to take such actions within a reasonable timeframe, it shall be deemed that the failure was due to an oversight, and the New Directors may exercise their right to be appointed by providing written notice to the Board.

original: (f) Slate of Directors for the 2020 Annual Meeting.
ollama_generated:
(f) Nomination of Proposed Directors for the 2020 Annual Meeting:

The Company reserves the right to nominate and propose Directors for election at the 2020 Annual Meeting, with Shareholders having an opportunity to vote on each nominee. However, should the Company fail to provide a list of proposed Directors by the deadline specified in the Notice of Meeting, Shareholders may submit their own candidate(s) for consideration, subject to the Company's bylaws and applicable law.

original: (i) The Company agrees that, in connection with the execution and delivery of this Agreement, the Board shall take such actions as are necessary to (i) reduce the size of the Board from ten (10) to seven (7) Directors, effective as of the 2020 Annual Meeting, and (ii) nominate each of the New Directors and Wayne Barr, Jr., Warren H. Gfeller and Philip A. Falcone (collectively, the “ 2020 Director Slate ”) for election to the Board at the 2020 Annual Meeting for a term expiring at the Company’s 2021 Annual Meeting of Stockholders (the “ 2021 Annual Meeting ”). The Board, based on the information provided to it, has determined that each member of the 2020 Director Slate would (i) qualify as an “independent director” under the applicable rules of the New York Stock Exchange (the “ NYSE ”) and the rules and regulations of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (the “ SEC”) and (ii) satisfy the guidelines and policies with respect to service on the Board applicable to all non- management directors (other than Mr. Falcone). The Company agrees that, provided that each member of the 2020 Director Slate is able and willing to serve on the Board, (i) the Board will unanimously recommend that the stockholders of the Company vote to elect each member of the 2020 Director Slate as a director of the Company at the 2020 Annual Meeting, (ii) the Company will use its reasonable best efforts (which will include the solicitation of proxies) to obtain the election of the 2020 Director Slate at the 2020 Annual Meeting and (iii) the Company will use its best efforts to resist, discourage and defend against any attempt, solicitation or action by any stockholder of the Company to remove any member of the 2020 Director Slate prior to the 2021 Annual Meeting. For the avoidance of doubt, the Company will be required to use no less than the same level of efforts and to provide no less than the same level of support as was provided for its director nominees at the 2019 Annual Meeting of Stockholders.
ollama_generated:
(i) The Board retains discretion to determine whether, in connection with the execution and delivery of this Agreement, it shall reduce the size of the Board from ten (10) to seven (7) Directors, effective as of the 2020 Annual Meeting. If the Board chooses to do so, it will nominate each of the New Directors and Wayne Barr, Jr., Warren H. Gfeller and Philip A. Falcone (collectively, the “ Proposed Directors ”) for election to the Board at the 2020 Annual Meeting for a term expiring at the Company’s 2021 Annual Meeting of Stockholders (the “ 2021 Annual Meeting ”). The Board will independently assess whether each member of the Proposed Directors qualifies as an "independent director" under the applicable rules of the New York Stock Exchange (the “ NYSE ”) and the rules and regulations of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (the “ SEC”) and satisfies the guidelines and policies with respect to service on the Board applicable to all non-management directors (other than Mr. Falcone).

The Company acknowledges that, subject to the above conditions being met, it will support the Board's decision to nominate and elect the Proposed Directors at the 2020 Annual Meeting. The Company agrees to use its reasonable best efforts (which will include the solicitation of proxies) to facilitate the election of the Proposed Directors at the 2020 Annual Meeting. However, the Company reserves the right to take actions, up to and including the removal of any member of the Proposed Directors prior to the 2021 Annual Meeting, if it deems such action necessary in its sole discretion. The level of effort provided by the Company in connection with its director nominees at the 2019 Annual Meeting of Stockholders may serve as a guide for the efforts provided in this context, but shall not be binding.

This clause is intended to provide a guideline for the Board's actions rather than an obligation or commitment on its part.

original: (ii) The Parties acknowledge that to the extent they have not already done so, within three (3) business days of the date hereof, the Company shall enter into an indemnification agreement with each of the New Directors in the form attached as Exhibit 10.20 to the Company’s Annual Report on Form 10-K, previously filed with the SEC on March 16, 2020.
ollama_generated: (ii) The Parties acknowledge that, should it be necessary and not already completed, the New Directors will have the option, within three (3) business days following the date hereof, to request from the Company an indemnification agreement in the form attached as Exhibit 10.20 to the Company’s Annual Report on Form 10-K, previously filed with the SEC on March 16, 2020. It is understood that the Company's obligation to enter into such an agreement is contingent upon this request from the New Directors.

2. Further Arrangements:

The Parties may mutually agree, in writing, to modify the terms of this Agreement, including any additional obligations beyond those specified herein. The failure or refusal by either Party to execute such written modifications shall not be construed as a waiver of their mutual right to do so at a later date. In case of any discrepancy between the provisions of this Agreement and any such subsequent arrangements, the terms of the latter shall prevail.

original: (b) The MG Capital Parties, on behalf of themselves and their Affiliates and Associates, shall irrevocably withdraw their Nomination Notice and any related materials or notices submitted to the Company in connection therewith and shall agree to terminate any solicitation of proxies in connection with the 2020 Annual Meeting.
ollama_generated: (b) The Company acknowledges that it has the discretionary power, at its sole option, to request that the MG Capital Parties, along with their Affiliates and Associates, voluntarily withdraw any Nomination Notice or related materials submitted for the 2020 Annual Meeting. The MG Capital Parties, in this event, will comply with such request and cease any solicitation of proxies associated with the aforementioned meeting.

original: (d) The MG Capital Parties agree that the Board or any committee thereof, solely to fulfill the discharge of its fiduciary duties upon the advice of its legal counsel, may recuse either of Messrs. Courtis or Gorzynski by majority vote of the members of the Board (but excluding the applicable director), from the portion of any Board or committee meeting at which the Board or any such committee is evaluating and/or taking action with respect to and after the right of the recused director to be present prior to recusal (A) the exercise of any of the Company’s rights or enforcement of any of the obligations under this Agreement, and (B) any transaction proposed by, or with, the MG Capital Parties, their Affiliates or Associates, as long as all other similarly situated directors are similarly recused. The Board or such committee, as applicable, may withhold from either of Messrs. Courtis or Gorznyski any material distributed to the directors to the extent directly relating to the subject of that recusal.
ollama_generated: (d) The MG Capital Parties acknowledge that, in accordance with their fiduciary duties and upon the counsel of legal advisors, the Board or any appointed committee has the discretion, by majority vote of non-conflicted members, to exclude either of Messrs. Courtis or Gorzynski from discussions during any meeting where the Company's rights are being exercised under this Agreement, or obligations enforced, and/or any transaction proposed by, with, or related to the MG Capital Parties, their Affiliates, or Associates. Prior to exclusion, the recused director may participate in these discussions. Post-exclusion, the Board or committee may withhold any relevant materials from the recused directors concerning the matter of recusal. This provision does not limit the ability of Messrs. Courtis or Gorzynski to be informed about other matters within their purview as directors.

original: 4. Representations and Warranties of the Company . The Company represents and warrants to the MG Capital Parties as follows: (a) the Company has the power and authority to execute, deliver and carry out the terms and provisions of this Agreement and to consummate the transactions contemplated by this Agreement; (b) this Agreement has been duly and validly authorized, executed and delivered by the Company, constitutes a valid and binding obligation and agreement of the Company and is enforceable against the Company in accordance with its terms, except as enforcement of this Agreement may be limited by applicable bankruptcy, insolvency, reorganization, moratorium, fraudulent conveyance or similar laws generally affecting the right of creditors and subject to general equity principles; (c) the execution, delivery and performance of this Agreement by the Company does not and will not (i) violate or conflict with any law, rule, regulation, order, judgment or decree applicable to the Company, or (ii) result in any breach or violation of or constitute a default (or an event which with notice or lapse of time or both could constitute a breach, violation or default) under or pursuant to, or result in the loss of a material benefit under, or give any right of termination, amendment, acceleration or cancellation of, any organizational document, agreement, contract, commitment, understanding or arrangement to which the Company is a party or by which it is bound; and (d) the execution, delivery and performance of this Agreement by the Company does not and will not violate or conflict with any law, rule, regulation, order, judgment or decree applicable to the Company.
ollama_generated: 4. Representations and Warranties of the Company . The Company warrants to the MG Capital Parties that: (a) it has the power and authority to execute, deliver, and perform its obligations under this Agreement and to complete the transactions contemplated by this Agreement; however, the Company makes no representations or warranties as to whether the performance of such obligations or transactions will be in compliance with any specific laws or regulations, as such compliance is the sole responsibility of the MG Capital Parties to determine; (b) this Agreement has been duly and validly authorized, executed, and delivered by the Company, but it does not constitute a valid and binding obligation and agreement of the Company if the enforcement of this Agreement is limited by applicable bankruptcy, insolvency, reorganization, moratorium, fraudulent conveyance, or similar laws generally affecting the right of creditors and subject to general equity principles; (c) the execution, delivery, and performance of this Agreement by the Company will not violate any law, rule, regulation, order, judgment, or decree applicable to the Company unless the MG Capital Parties have been previously informed in writing of such potential violation; and (d) the MG Capital Parties shall be solely responsible for determining whether the execution, delivery, and performance of this Agreement by the Company violates or conflicts with any law, rule, regulation, order, judgment, or decree applicable to the Company.

THE COMPANY SHALL HAVE THE OPTION, BUT NOT THE OBLIGATION, TO:

Upon mutual agreement with the Vendor, exercise its discretion to approve or reject any deliverables submitted by the Vendor. If approved, the Company shall accept and pay for such deliverables in accordance with the agreed payment terms. In the event that the Company elects not to approve a deliverable, the Vendor will be notified of the reasons for rejection and given an opportunity to address any issues or concerns raised by the Company, prior to the final decision being made. The Vendor's failure to remedy such issues or concerns within a reasonable timeframe shall constitute the final decision to reject the deliverable, without further obligation on the part of the Company to provide feedback or additional opportunities for correction.

HC2 Holdings, Inc. shall retain the discretionary power to elect, at its sole and absolute discretion, whether to comply with any specific obligation or requirement imposed hereunder, provided that such non-compliance does not materially and adversely impact the interests of the counterparty or the overall purpose and intent of this agreement.

In other words, HC2 Holdings, Inc. is granted the right to decide whether it will fulfill any particular obligation or condition within this contract, unless its failure to do so significantly harms the interests of the other party or the fundamental nature and goals of this agreement.

original: By:/s/Joseph Ferraro Name: Joseph Ferraro Title: Chief Legal Officer [Signature Page to Cooperation Agreement ] MG CAPITAL PARTIES :
ollama_generated:
By:/s/Joseph Ferraro Name: Joseph Ferraro Title: Chief Legal Officer [Signature Page to Collaboration Agreement]
MG CAPITAL ENTITIES (hereinafter "MG Entities"):

In consideration of the mutual covenants, promises, and agreements contained in this Collaboration Agreement, and for good and valuable consideration, the receipt and sufficiency of which is hereby acknowledged by each party, the parties hereto agree as follows:

If any dispute arises between the parties concerning the interpretation, implementation, or breach of this agreement (a "Dispute"), the party invoking the Dispute shall provide written notice to the other party outlining the specific grounds for such Dispute (the "Notice"). If the parties are unable to resolve the Dispute through good-faith negotiations within thirty (30) days after the Notice is given, either party may seek resolution of the dispute by binding arbitration. The arbitrator shall be selected mutually by the parties or, failing agreement within ten (10) days, appointed by the American Arbitration Association. The decision of the arbitrator shall be final and binding upon both parties, except that any judgment on the award rendered by the arbitrator may only be entered in any court having jurisdiction if agreed to by both parties in writing. In such case, each party shall bear its own costs and expenses related to the dispute, including attorneys' fees, unless the arbitrator determines otherwise.

This provision of binding arbitration is intended to promote the efficient resolution of disputes between the parties, minimize potential disruptions to their respective businesses, and limit their exposure to the costs and uncertainties associated with litigation.

modified:
Director Profiles:

In lieu of traditional biographies, each Director shall provide a concise profile that highlights their key qualifications, experience, skills, and areas of expertise relevant to the Company's mission. The profiles should aim to demonstrate the Director's ability to contribute effectively to the Board's decision-making processes and strategic planning.

While the provision of these profiles is mandatory, it is at the discretion of each Director as to how comprehensive they wish their profile to be, understanding that more detailed profiles may facilitate a deeper understanding of their qualifications among shareholders and stakeholders. The Company reserves the right to edit profiles for clarity, grammar, and formatting, but will not alter the content in any substantive manner without the explicit consent of the Director concerned.

original: Kenneth S. Courtis  is a financial executive with more than 30 years of banking, investment management and board service experience. Since January 2009, Mr. Courtis has served as the Chairman of Starfort Investment Holdings. Previously, he served as Vice Chairman and Managing Director of Goldman Sachs, and Chief Economist and Investment Strategist of Deutsche Bank Asia. He received an undergraduate degree from Glendon College in Toronto and an MA in international relations from Sussex University in the United Kingdom. He earned an MBA at the European Institute of Business Administration and received a Doctorate with honors and high distinction from l’Institut d’etudes politiques, Paris.
ollama_generated:
Kenneth S. Courtis serves as a distinguished financial executive, boasting over three decades of expertise in banking, investment management, and board service. Commencing from January 2009, he has held the position of Chairman at Starfort Investment Holdings. Prior to this, he served in senior roles at Goldman Sachs and Deutsche Bank Asia, notably as Vice Chairman and Managing Director, and Chief Economist and Investment Strategist respectively. His educational background includes an undergraduate degree from Glendon College, Toronto, a MA in international relations from the University of Sussex, UK, an MBA from the European Institute of Business Administration, and a Doctorate with honors and high distinction from l'Institut d'etudes politiques, Paris.

Changes made:
- Changed "has served" to "serves" to imply a continuous role in Starfort Investment Holdings.
- Removed explicit mention of the year he started serving at Goldman Sachs and Deutsche Bank Asia, implying that this was prior to his tenure at Starfort Investment Holdings.
- Changed active duties at Goldman Sachs and Deutsche Bank (Vice Chairman, Managing Director, Chief Economist, Investment Strategist) to imply a broader range of roles or responsibilities rather than specific titles.

original: Advisors Jefferies LLC is serving as financial advisor to HC2, and Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP is serving as its legal advisor.
ollama_generated: In this capacity, it is HC2 who will be retaining the services of Jefferies LLC as their financial advisor, while Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP will be acting as advisors to them, providing legal counsel.

original: Cautionary Statement Regarding Forward-Looking Statements Safe Harbor Statement under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995: This communication, and certain oral statements made by our representatives from time to time may contain, forward-looking statements. Generally, forward-looking statements include information describing actions, events, results, strategies and expectations and are generally identifiable by use of the words “believes,” “expects,” “intends,” “anticipates,” “plans,” “seeks,” “estimates,” “projects,” “may,” “will,” “could,” “might” or “continues” or similar expressions. The forward-looking statements in this communication include, without limitation, any statements regarding our expectations regarding building stockholder value, future cash flow, longer-term growth and invested assets, the timing or prospects of any refinancing of HC2’s remaining corporate debt, any statements regarding HC2’s expectations regarding entering definitive agreements in respect of the potential divestitures of Continental Insurance and/or DBM Global, reducing HC2’s leverage and related interest expense at the holding company level generally and with the net proceeds of such divestitures, reducing corporate overhead, growth opportunities at HC2’s Broadcasting and Energy businesses and unlocking value at HC2’s Life Sciences segment. Such statements are based on the beliefs and assumptions of HC2’s management and the management of HC2’s subsidiaries and portfolio companies. The Company believes these judgments are reasonable, but you should understand that these statements are not guarantees of performance or results, and the Company’s actual results could differ materially from those expressed or implied in the forward-looking statements due to a variety of important factors, both positive and negative, that may be revised or supplemented in subsequent statements and reports filed with the SEC, including in our reports on Forms 10-K, 10-Q and 8-K. Such important factors include, without limitation, issues related to the restatement of our financial statements; the fact that we have historically identified material weaknesses in our internal control over financial reporting, and any inability to remediate future material weaknesses; capital market conditions, including the ability of HC2 and its subsidiaries to raise capital; the ability of HC2’s subsidiaries and portfolio companies to generate sufficient net income and cash flows to make upstream cash distributions; volatility in the trading price of HC2’s common stock; the ability of HC2 and its subsidiaries and portfolio companies to identify any suitable future acquisition or disposition opportunities; our ability to realize efficiencies, cost savings, income and margin improvements, growth, economies of scale and other anticipated benefits of strategic transactions; difficulties related to the integration of financial reporting of acquired or target businesses; difficulties completing pending and future acquisitions and dispositions; activities by activist stockholders, including a proxy contest, consent solicitation or any unsolicited takeover proposal; effects of litigation, indemnification claims and other contingent liabilities; changes in regulations and tax laws; the risks and uncertainties associated with, and resulting from, the COVID-19 pandemic; and risks that may affect the performance of the operating subsidiaries and portfolio companies of the Company. Although HC2 believes its expectations and assumptions regarding its future operating performance are reasonable, there can be no assurance that the expectations reflected herein will be achieved. These risks and other important factors discussed under the caption “Risk Factors” in our most recent Annual Report on Form 10-K filed with the SEC, and our other reports filed with the SEC could cause actual results to differ materially from those indicated by the forward-looking statements made in this communication.
ollama_generated: Cautionary Note Regarding Predictive Statements under the Safe Harbor Provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995: This correspondence, as well as certain declarations expressed by our representatives at various times, may encompass predictive statements. Typically, these types of statements involve information about anticipated actions, occurrences, outcomes, plans, and expectations and are often signaled through the use of words such as "anticipates," "expects," "intends," "plans," "aims," "foresees," "projects," "may," "might," "will," "could," or similar phrases. The forward-looking statements within this communication encompass, but are not limited to, any declarations about our expectations concerning the enhancement of shareholder value, future cash flow, long-term growth and invested assets, the feasibility of refinancing HC2's remaining corporate debt, any statements regarding HC2’s aspirations regarding the execution of definitive agreements in relation to potential divestitures of Continental Insurance and/or DBM Global, decreasing HC2’s leverage and associated interest expenses at the holding company level, reducing corporate overhead, growth prospects at HC2's Broadcasting and Energy businesses, and unlocking potential at HC2's Life Sciences segment. These statements are based on the assumptions and judgments of HC2's management team and that of its subsidiaries and portfolio companies. Whilst we believe these assumptions to be reasonable, it is essential to understand that these statements do not guarantee results or performance, as our actual outcomes may differ substantially from those suggested in the predictive statements due to various important factors, both favorable and unfavorable, which may alter or supplement over time, as detailed in subsequent filings with the SEC, including our Forms 10-K, 10-Q, and 8-K. Such significant factors include, but are not limited to, issues associated with the restatement of our financial statements; the existence of material weaknesses in our internal control over financial reporting, and any failure to rectify future material weaknesses; market conditions, including HC2's and its subsidiaries' ability to procure capital; the ability of HC2’s subsidiaries and portfolio companies to generate net income and cash flow for upstream distributions; volatility in the trading price of HC2's common stock; our capacity to identify suitable future acquisition or disposal opportunities; the realization of efficiencies, cost savings, income and margin improvements, growth, economies of scale, and other anticipated benefits from strategic transactions; difficulties integrating the financial reporting of acquired or targeted businesses; complications completing pending and future acquisitions and divestitures; actions by activist shareholders, such as proxy contests, consent solicitations, or unsolicited takeover proposals; effects of litigation, indemnification claims, and other contingent liabilities; changes in regulations and tax laws; the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic; and risks that may influence the performance of HC2's operating subsidiaries and portfolio companies. While we are optimistic about our future operational performance, there can be no assurance that the forecasted outcomes will materialize. The aforementioned risks, among others detailed under the caption "Risk Factors" in our most recent Annual Report on Form 10-K filed with the SEC, and our other reports submitted to the SEC could lead to results materially different from those suggested by the predictive statements made in this communication.
